newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile Quebrada Blanca union expects talks Thurs.
newsitem.headline: Chile Quebrada Blanca union expects talks Thurs.

text.p: Union leaders at Chile's Quebrada Blanca copper mine said they hoped that talks would begin Thursday with management to resolve the week-long strike over pay at the pit.
"Company officials should arrive in Iquique today and we hope to make an attempt to normalize relations," union secretary Victor Vielma told Reuters by telephone from Iquique.
But Quebrada Blanca CEO James Drake denied that the company was planning to return to the negotiating table and revise its last pay offer.
"No further negotiations will take place. Staff travelling to Iquique are part of the normal rotation of personnel," he said.
"We have offered a 15 percent real increase over three years are not prepared to go beyond that."
The main sticking point is the unions' demand for an extra high-altitude bonus for working at the mine which lies on a barren plateau over 4,000 meters above sea level.
Quebrada Blanca is operating at around 30 percent of capacity using non-union labor and administrative staff to churn out copper cathodes from the tankhouses, said Vielma.
Drake said Tuesday that the 75,000 tonne a year pit was running at 50 percent of design capacity.
Quebrada Blanca is controlled by Vancouver-based Cominco Ltd Cominco Resources and Teck Resources International. ((-- Margaret Orgill, Santiago newsroom, 562-699-5595x212))
